answer: The author concludes the narrative with this passage as gardens are unable to thrive when the ground is covered with snow. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the narrative reaches a satisfactory conclusion. In the tale, the girl purchases a hibiscus that evokes memories of her homeland. Winter Hibiscus" revolves around a young girl named Saeng, who migrated from Vietnam to the @ORGANIZATION1. After failing her driver's test, she makes her way home and discovers a hibiscus. Her vow demonstrates her resolve not to succumb despite her initial setback. As exemplified by the quote, "Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral" (Ho), this elucidates the profound significance the plant held for her. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate Saeng's determination. Her family left behind a great deal in Vietnam. She retained the memories of her grandmother and the hibiscus. The author concludes the narrative with this statement as it demonstrates the girl's willingness to surmount obstacles. In the concluding paragraph, when she stated that she would retake the test in the spring, a time when all the snow thaws and the hibiscus blossoms, she made this declaration because it is her preferred season of the year. I am of the opinion that the author concluded the story with that paragraph to convey to readers that Saeng is a survivor, much like the hibiscus. Saeng has yet to fully acclimate to America and perceives that this plant evokes memories of her homeland.

The author concludes the story in this manner because spring symbolizes a new beginning. The author concludes the sentence in this way to illustrate that Saeng is an extremely determined young woman. In the narrative, a young girl named Saeng undertakes an examination but unfortunately fails. She intends to retake it the following spring. This is why the last paragraph states: "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus is in bud, then I will take the test again." The author concludes the story with this ending. In the story, it mentions the hibiscus flowers. Thus, instead of simply stating she will retake the test next spring, it says when the hibiscus flowers bud, which will be springtime.

The author concludes the story in such a manner to convey to the readers that the daughter, Saeng, will return and retake the test. She has a profound affection for the garden; consequently, she will not forget the rejuvenating effect spring has had on her.

Minfong, who concludes "Winter Hibiscus" with this paragraph, does so because it showcases @CAPS1's resolve to achieve success in her new country despite the impediments she encounters. (Ho @NUM1). Saeng is aware that she can adapt and is determined to succeed. In the story, @ORGANIZATION1, penned by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the narrative with the final paragraph as he aims to convey that when the flower revives and commences a new phase, Saeng will embark on a fresh start by retaking the test. The author appended the final paragraph as Saeng's vow enables the reader to empathize with Saeng and her anguish, while also appreciating her optimism that circumstances will improve. Winter Hibiscus" by @CAPS1 Ho delves into an individual's pursuit of acceptance and adjustment to life's transformations. Saeng, the protagonist in the story, is grappling with her recent relocation from her Asian homeland to America. After failing a test, Saeng expends a considerable sum of money on a flower. When she seeks solace from her mother, Saeng silently makes a vow to herself. She vows, "When they return in the spring, when the snows thaw and the geese come back and this hibiscus is in bud, then I will retake that test." @CAPS1 Ho chose to conclude the story in this manner as it epitomizes the journey of adaptation. Individually, Saeng was able to make a vow that revealed her acceptance of her new foreign abode in America, despite her enduring remembrance of her homeland.

The author concludes this paragraph in the article because Ron is infatuated with the plant and utilizes it as a time - keeper to determine when she can take the test. If one is not a @CAPS1.S citizen, they are only permitted to take the driver's test once a year. This conclusion ties together Ron's unique relationship with the plant and the regulatory constraint regarding the driver's test, highlighting the significance of the plant in Ron's decision - making process.

The rationale for the author's decision to conclude the story with this paragraph is that Saeng aspires to undertake something beneficial for herself. This conclusion showcases Saeng's self - awareness and her proactive approach towards achieving personal growth and contentment.

Saeng is under the impression that having failed the driving test, she will be unable to transition in a new country as she embarks on a quest to uncover her past. In plants, she discovers her past, recalling Vietnam in profound sorrow. The narration posits, “A wave of such depth and intensity that it pricked Saeng's eyes...” (No). She reminisces about and yearns for everything she once had; she longs for her country, her grandmother, and her former life. She returned home to her mother with a plant, disappointing her mother with the expense, yet her mother comprehends her pain. The narration states, “It's a beautiful plant,” she finally uttered sorrowfully, “you got it.” (No). Eventually, Saeng realizes the impact this plant has on her and how effortlessly it endures, and she makes a vow to herself. The narration states, “And if this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.”

In the narrative “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is to illustrate or accentuate that if the hibiscus, a plant evoking memories of her homeland, can persevere, so can she. In the story, after the author failed her driving test and was on her way home, the sight of the flowers rekindled memories of home and connected her to her past, alleviating her sense of solitude. For instance, when the author remarks, “A wave of loss so profound and intense that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her.” This indicates her longing for home, and the flower provided a profound connection to her recollections. Additionally, when she says, “like the geese in the distinctive V against the sky,” it shows that the geese, much like her, were migrating to a new place to commence anew. This made her believe that if they could adapt and change, she too would be able to do so over time. In conclusion, the ending serves to further emphasize her sentiments towards her hometown and the new town she inhabits.

The author concludes the story in such a manner as to draw parallels with the concepts of adaptation, change, and starting afresh. For example, geese migrate when the weather turns cold but always return, giving their habitat another opportunity. The hibiscus is another prime example; it typically buds on @DATE1 and endures the winter without perishing. It always makes a comeback. Saeng has evidently grasped this and pledged to retake her driver's test, as she believes it may yield a different outcome this time. The author aims to convey the message of “do not surrender.”

Determination, assistance, and fortitude—these are the factors that lead me to believe the author concludes the story with the given paragraph. Firstly, determination is a key reason why Saeng will revisit and retake the test. Saeng failed her driver's test on the initial attempt and intends to bide her time and try again. She is resolute in taking alternative measures to pass the test. Secondly, I believe that assistance is a crucial factor behind the author's choice of this concluding paragraph. The author is demonstrating that she will return and be well - prepared. Finally, fortitude is the last significant factor for the author's selection of this paragraph to end the story. Saeng believes that the hibiscus plant will endow her with the strength to pass the test. The author concludes with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng will return and emerge stronger than before. These are the reasons why I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph.

Mingfong Ho concludes “Winter Hibiscus” with the passage, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This concluding paragraph reveals that Saeng will not abandon her struggle to acclimate to this new environment. The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph to illustrate the transformation of Saeng. Initially, Saeng was averse to taking the test and lacked self - assurance. The author concludes the story with the statement “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with Saeng's thoughts. The idea of attempting the test when the hibiscus begins to bud serves to unify the narrative. The author concluded the narrative with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” as the author intended the reader to observe the profound bond between the mother and the child through gardening. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the tale with a paragraph that evokes emotions. The paragraph reveals that the girl, Saeng, is resolute in passing the test. For instance, the text states, “If the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This indicates that despite failing it once, she will not allow that set - back to impede her progress. The girl also subtly expresses her sentiments towards the geese and the plant. As the text mentions, “When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding.” This implies that she does not regret purchasing the hibiscus, further highlighting her positive connection to these natural elements.

The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” in this fashion as she is cultivating a sense of optimism that Saeng harbors for the future. Saeng was deeply despondent while walking home after failing her driver's test. The author depicts this scene as “The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds.” The winter and cold conditions symbolize Saeng's loss of hope. When she arrives home and shows her mother the hibiscus, her mother remarks that it is “strong enough to make it through the cold months here.” This symbolizes Saeng's ability to persevere as well. At the story's end, Saeng spots geese and realizes that “many of the things she had once regarded as peculiar had, through the consistent recurrence of seasons, become nearly familiar to her.” This illustrates that she is truly adapting to her new home and has hope for the arrival of spring, the return of the geese, and the blooming of the hibiscus.

Her objective in hunting was to capture them; this was the entirety of her goal and purpose. She was attempting to catch geese, having witnessed her grandparents endeavor to do so. Consequently, this is the reason she made that final statement.

The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph as she desires readers to comprehend that she did not abandon the plant and that she is resolute. For instance, the story states that Saeng said, “I - I failed the test.” She felt as if she had not achieved what she intended. Thus, at the story's conclusion, she declared, “I will take that test again.” This demonstrates the kind of person she is, and she will not simply surrender because she failed the first time.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the narrative with this paragraph because during spring, all things are reborn, and by spring, Saeng will have acclimated to her surroundings. An illustration of this is when the author states, “She realized that many of the things she had once regarded as strange had, through the quiet recurrence of season after season, become nearly familiar to her.” This implies that with each season, she becomes more accustomed to her new home, and it becomes more like her. Another instance is when the author writes, “She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.” This evokes memories of her old home as she watches the geese.

In the story, Saeng is compelled to adapt to an abrupt transformation when her family relocates from Vietnam to the United States. This indicates that Saeng can surmount the challenges presented by the new country and is determined to do so. This paragraph is placed at the story's conclusion because it reflects the themes of change and adaptation throughout the narrative, with a particular emphasis on reflection. The author takes the time to elucidate how each individual element in the story reminds Saeng of her old home. In an attempt to elevate the story's tone from regret and sadness to hope and optimism, the author revisits each element in the final paragraph, demonstrating that there is hope for Saeng and her family.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it portrays Saeng as a compassionate individual towards nature. This can be inferred from the quote, “One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it.” This quote indicates that she cares about the minutiae of nature. I surmise that the author concludes the narrative with that paragraph as it aids in elucidating the significance of the hibiscus. The hibiscus holds great importance for her and her culture. The author concludes the passage with this paragraph to demonstrate that after all the turmoil and disarray, she recognizes that it will require time to adjust. She realizes that given time to recuperate and commence anew, she will be prepared, much like the plant.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as she desires to set a future goal for herself. She aspires to pass the test and will exert great effort to achieve this next year. Through this statement, Saeng demonstrates an unwavering resolve not to abandon hope, to embrace new opportunities fairly, and to cherish the memory of her homeland. The author's decision to end the story in such an inspiring manner reinforces the central theme, revealing that a few words can convey a wealth of wisdom.

The author opted to conclude the story with the final paragraph for multiple reasons. Saeng declares her intention to retake her driving test in the spring. Traditionally, spring symbolizes a fresh start or a new chance. Concluding the story with this archetype suggests that in the future, Saeng will have an opportunity to succeed in her test and make the most of her time in @LOCATION1, adapting to her new life. When she purchases the hibiscus plant, it evokes memories of her former home and the wonderful experiences she had there. The plant appears to instill hope in her, and the last paragraph of the story mentions the hibiscus. This indicates that having the hibiscus nearby will offer her hope of passing the test and adjusting to @LOCATION1 while still recalling her native Vietnam.

The author concludes the narrative with this statement to signify that when the plants resume their growth and the geese return, she will make another attempt. For instance, the plants must regenerate their petals, and the geese must rebuild their habitats and forage for food. The author implies that she will retake the test when the geese return and the plants flourish once more, highlighting the cyclical nature of renewal and opportunity.

The author penned this paragraph because the character entered the house to prepare dinner and would not see the garden again until later. With winter approaching, she would no longer play outdoors until the season passed. As she stated, "In the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This quotation elucidates the author's rationale for concluding the story with this paragraph, emphasizing the connection between the changing seasons, personal perseverance, and the anticipation of new beginnings.

I must assert that the reason the narrator concluded with this is that it can be regarded as a solution when contemplated. Moreover, one typically places the solution solely at the end, which is precisely why she chose to position it there.

The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph as it demonstrates that Saeng is not capitulating and has discovered a pastime to anticipate. For instance, “the winter hibiscus was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it; overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by.” This is the rationale behind the author's decision to conclude the story with this paragraph.

The author concluded the narrative with that particular quote as it showcases an appreciation and understanding of the beauty and wonders of nature. Saeng expended a substantial amount of money to acquire a unique flower known as dok faeng - nol. Saeng was attempting to obtain a driver's license but was failing the test. During her test, she chanced upon that plant. Despite being ashamed of her test failure, she still presented the flower she had found to her mother, which differed from the one at home. Her mother was delighted with the flowers and comprehended that Saeng had failed her test. Her mother remarked about the flower, “Its flowers aren't as lovely, but it's robust enough to endure the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That's what matters.” This was a figurative expression suggesting that there is hope for Saeng to pass her test when she has acquired more skills and is prepared to attempt it again. Additionally, the geese flying away for the winter and returning in the spring symbolize a fresh start towards success.
The author concludes in this manner because when the external environment becomes warm and pleasant, they will endeavor to take the test once more, as the current outdoor conditions are unfavorable.

In actuality, it is an extremely potent final statement. Despite failing her driver's test, she has recognized that she must persevere in being resilient and patient. Soon, the geese will return, and the snow will thaw, and she will “re - engage” to take her test with the determination to succeed. Saeng purchased the hibiscus to evoke a sense of being back in Vietnam, believing it could fill the void in her heart where she yearns for her homeland. “I paid nineteen dollars for it,” she says, indicating both her disappointment at failing the test and the realization that a flower that is freely available in Vietnam is exorbitantly priced in the United States. As a tropical flower, the hibiscus will bloom in the spring, signifying the time when she will be ready to retake the test.

The author concludes the narrative with this ending as it demonstrates that should the plant revive and blossom, she will return to take the examination and strive to succeed this time. She is aware that it will be arduous for her to retake and pass this test, yet she is confident in her ability, just as she is certain that the plant will endure the winter and resurface to bloom in the spring. This instills in her the assurance that she can pass this test if the plant can withstand the harsh winter they are experiencing. Consequently, this is the reason the author concluded the story in such a manner.

In my estimation, the author concludes the story by stating that she will retake the driver's test because not only will she attempt the driver's test anew, but she will also attain greater comfort in her life. The driver's test is not the primary issue; rather, it is the adaptation to her new environment that is causing Saeng profound distress. For instance, in lines @NUM1, Saeng's thoughts are "A wave of loss so profound and powerful stung Saeng's eyes now and swept over her," and "in the warm, moist refuge of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept." This indicates that Saeng is struggling to readjust to her new life and is reminded of her former memories from her place of origin, and she weeps because it has vanished. I believe that failing her driver's test was merely a minor trigger that finally led her to cry due to the stress, and when she said, "and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again," it implies that she will surmount all obstacles and move forward.

It was judicious of the author to conclude the story with this paragraph. Saeng held a deep affection for the hibiscus; thus, when spring arrives and the hibiscus blossoms, it will be an opportune moment to retake the test after having previously failed it. This would likely bolster her confidence to retake the driving test at the appropriate time. In conclusion, this is the rationale behind the author's choice to conclude the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story in this way as she is suggesting that she will evolve with the seasonal transition. She finds herself in a new country and has just failed her driver's test. She is disheartened, yet the hibiscus serves as a reminder of her homeland. In the story, @CAPS1's mother remarks, "I've witnessed this kind blooming along the lake; it is robust enough to endure the winter." I think Saeng can identify with this because if the flower can persevere through the winter, then she can thrive in a new country.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the narrative with this final paragraph: "When they return, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with that paragraph because at the onset, Saeng had procured a hibiscus plant as it reminded her of her hometown. ("Plants that she had not realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.") So she acquired it, but due to the inclement weather at the time, Saeng had to retrieve the plant promptly and plant it in the garden. However, she failed to do so in a timely manner. This is the reason for the statement "I will take that test again." And she will retake it during the spring when the hibiscus blossoms once more. This is why the author concluded the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the paragraph in this manner as it demonstrates that she is not inclined to abandon her efforts. I surmise this due to her silent vow to herself that she would retake the test during the spring. Additionally, it pertains to certain elements that are not entirely clear from the rather cryptic mention about "aiudieres" and "gains in old years seeds an ezing". In conclusion, this is the reason why the author concludes the paragraph in such a way.

The narrative "Winter Hibiscus" is penned by Minfong Ho. The author concludes the story with the excerpt, "When they return, Saeng silently vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snow thaws and the geese migrate back and this hibiscus begins to bud, then I shall take the test once more." The rationale behind this is to afford her time for adjustment. Saeng merely requires a modicum of solace as all of this is novel to her. These words employ figurative language as the geese reminded her of herself, "Almost familiar to her now. Like geese." In essence, this ending enriches the story's emotional resonance and character development.

The grass is burgeoning, the trees are sprouting buds, and the @CAPS1 are chirping. In the tale "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the narrative with a captivating paragraph. The paragraph reads, "When they return, Saeng silently vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snows dissolve and the geese make their way back and this hibiscus is in bloom, then I will undertake that test again." The author concludes the story with this particular paragraph, "When they return, Saeng silently vowed to herself in the spring, when the snows dissipate and the geese migrate back and this hibiscus is in the process of budding, then I will retake that test," in order to prompt the audience to engage in contemplation. The author concludes this narrative with this paragraph since the flower is referenced throughout the story, and the author states that when the hibiscus is in bloom, she will retake that test.

The author concludes this narrative with this paragraph as she is conveying to us what will transpire beyond the story we are perusing. It implies that when the snow thaws, she will commence anew and reconstruct the greenhouse.

The author concludes the narrative with that paragraph as it elucidates that Saeng will make another attempt once spring arrives. The author concludes the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” to illustrate that she will embark on a new endeavor with a fresh start. The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph to illustrate Saeng's resolve despite her melancholy. She yearns for Vietnam, yet she will attempt the test anew in the coming year. The author concludes the story with “In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because Saeng fails the test by expending her money on a Big Mac and lacking sufficient funds for the type of flower her mother had sent for. The author concludes the story with these final lines to establish a tone of hope that forms a theme. Final lines wield a profound influence on the reader as they are the last words encountered. In this story, Saeng alludes to the time “when the snow melts.” Here, the snow symbolizes the sorrow she has endured since leaving home. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the narrative with this paragraph as it unveils the significance of the Winter Hibiscus. In the story, Saeng relocates from Vietnam and experiences profound homesickness. She fails her driving examination and is extremely despondent. When she encounters the familiar plant, she is reminded of her homeland in Vietnam. The Winter Hibiscus evokes fond recollections of her grandmother and simple elements such as her finely - toothed buffalo - horn comb and the hibiscus hedge that would leave soft red petals in her well water. Upon seeing the familiar plant, “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.” This demonstrates the profound importance of the hibiscus to her. The author ended the story with that paragraph to illustrate how the winter hibiscus serves as a source of comfort for Saeng and will inspire her to perform better on her subsequent driving test.

After perusing “Winter Hibiscus,” it is evident that Saeng is a resolute individual with an affinity for nature. It is also discernible that she is determined to pass the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to indicate that in the forthcoming spring, Saeng will have another opportunity. The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, … then I will take the test again” because Saeng, like the hibiscus, requires time to develop. The author's conclusion conveys her sentiments. The author's conclusion implies, "When the snow melts, the geese return, and this hibiscus is in bloom, then I will retake that test." The author concludes the story in this manner as it reveals that Saeng must recuperate from the setback of failing the test before she can attempt it anew. In the narrative “Winter Hibiscus” penned by Minfong Ho, the author concluded the tale with a captivating paragraph. It read, “When they return, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow thaws and the geese migrate back and this hibiscus begins to bud, then I will retake the test” (@NUM1). Individuals are required to adapt to diverse cultures when they relocate. They can achieve this through a multitude of methods, such as forging new friendships and acclimating to the locale. Nevertheless, while adjusting to a new environment, one should also retain memories of their former home. This is precisely what Minfong Ho endeavors to convey in the concluding paragraph of the story, “Winter Hibiscus”. In the narrative, a teenage girl named Saeng emigrated from Vietnam to the @LOCATION2. She has numerous recollections of her past home while visiting a plant store. She purchases a plant that was prevalent in Vietnam and plants it in her garden. The final paragraph of the story states, “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that driving test again”. This showcases Saeng’s aspiration to assimilate into this culture by taking the driving test, as well as her desire to remember her past by nurturing the flower. This concluding paragraph encapsulates Saeng’s sentiment towards her native country and her determination to succeed in her new environment.
As she was making a solemn vow to herself that upon the return of spring, she would retake the driver's test.

The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph to demonstrate her resolve. When she states, “...when the snows dissolve and the geese reappear and his hibiscus is in bud, then I will undertake that test once more.” Saeng is elucidating how the geese possess the determination to fly back and the hibiscus has the resolve to bud anew; thus, why shouldn't she have the determination and self - assurance to retake the test. Saeng declared, “I - I failed the test.” It appears as though failing the driving test made her feel as if she were destined to fail in the new country. Nevertheless, after witnessing the geese's and hibiscus's tenacity amidst harsh circumstances, she became determined to attempt the test again.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to expound on how she has already taken the test and it is currently winter. She will retake the test when all the flora rejuvenates and commences anew. Saeng desires to retake the test to prove to her mother that she can pass it. She purchased a plant named Dorl Faeng - noi for nineteen dollars to prevent her mother from being disappointed. However, her mother was disheartened that she spent such a substantial amount of money on a plant.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it illustrates that when she encounters elements from her homeland and way of life, they will soothe her in her undertakings. The author seems to require items from her native land that assist her in making the most of situations and evoke pleasant recollections of her earlier life. I opine that whenever I aspire to perform well, it is beneficial to contemplate the positive aspects that hold great significance for me, so that I will be content and motivated to do well. The author is astute to wish to see those things before retaking her test because if she observes her plant thriving and recalls the sight of the geese, it will bring her good fortune.

The author opts to conclude the story with such a paragraph to illustrate that Saeng has acquired a fresh surge of hope from her recollections and the newly familiar elements in her new abode. The confluence of the failed driver's test and her separation from her original home instilled in Saeng a profound sense of loss. While Saeng is in the flower shop, “aware of loss so profound and intense that it pricked Saeng's eyes now enveloped her.” Throughout the remainder of the story, Saeng is depicted as still being despondent, leaving the reader uncertain whether she will recover. Then, her recuperation commences with the presence of familiar things. “The pungent aroma of bitter melon drifted out, and Saeng's mouth watered,” “The winter hibiscus was now planted in the ground,” and “overhead, a flock of Canada geese soared by, their faint honks distinct and – yes – familiar to Saeng now.” This realization that the geese are familiar to her paves the way for a new understanding and a fresh wave of hope. She acknowledges the fact that she is gradually becoming accustomed to many aspects of her new home that she initially regarded as peculiar. This is what the final paragraph conveys to the reader. It summarizes Saeng's newly discovered hope that she will learn not only to subsist in her new home but to flourish in it.

The author concludes the story with this statement as it reveals that, to her, the hibiscus symbolizes surmounting obstacles. It symbolizes this because she states, “...and the geese return and this is budding, I will take that test again” (Ho @NUM1). This indicates that despite failing the test this time, when the hibiscus grows larger, she will retake the test, signifying perseverance or the act of overcoming obstacles. Additionally, I believe that this symbolizes overcoming obstacles because it “imparts strength from her old country.” This demonstrates that it symbolizes overcoming obstacles as it will aid her in conquering this test. It will achieve this by bestowing strength upon her or offering her solace. From this, one can discern that the author concludes the story with this statement to emphasize the significance of the hibiscus as a symbol of hope and the ability to overcome challenges.

I am convinced that the author concludes the narrative with this paragraph as it indicates that Saeng is self - assured and prepared to return and undertake the test. Saeng holds a positive self - perception and desires to pursue this course of action.

The author brings the story to a close with this paragraph due to Saeng's engagement in a test. Another rationale for the author's decision to conclude the story with this paragraph is that the narrative revolved around spring, gardening, and the associated way of life for the characters. The paragraph discusses spring and flowers. The daughter and mother sustain themselves through the cultivation of vegetables and fruits.

The final paragraph of the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho holds significance for the narrative. This concluding paragraph provides a definitive ending, enabling the reader to precisely anticipate future events. This passage serves as a highly meaningful conclusion to the story as it embodies symbols within the narrative. The author implies that the hibiscus is of great importance to the protagonist. Alongside the hibiscus, the geese and the melting snow also symbolize a fresh start and a new beginning. These symbols are crucial to her as they offer her an opportunity to start anew, and she perceives this in the winter hibiscus.

Saeng was deeply perturbed upon learning that she had not passed the test, and to her, it felt like a letdown or a disappointment. This sentence showcases the ambition and tenacity that Saeng possesses, which will enable her to eventually pass this test.

The author concludes the story with the moment “when they come back...” to illustrate how Saeng has undergone a transformation throughout the plot. At the beginning, she describes her new home as “walking into another world.” As a teenager, she had to relocate from Vietnam, where traditions diverge significantly from those in the United States. Nevertheless, there is one plant, the winter Hibiscus, that bears similarity. This plant bridges her former life and home with the present one. Adapting to the situation of moving was arduous, but the plant evoked familiar scents, and the “familiar fragrance” filled her lungs. It was even challenging for Saeng to utter the words “at home” without breaking into tears. Once the winter Hibiscus was planted, it brought about a change in Saeng, and she realized that she needed to appreciate what she had. In summary, the author ended the story with that paragraph because it revealed how closely the plant mirrored Saeng and how her outlook on life had been modified.

I perceive that the author concludes the narrative with this phrase as a means of demonstrating how Saeng is adapting to her new abode while still cherishing her former one. The essence of the sentence is that Saeng will retake her test in the spring, illustrating her tenacity. Nevertheless, the sentence also reveals how Saeng is acquainting herself with her new land. She states, “when the snows melt and the geese return,” which is significant because the geese and the snow are characteristic of her current home, and she now accepts them. However, Saeng also remarks, “when this hibiscus is budding,” and this indicates that Saeng is still reminiscing about her old home, as the plant is her link to the memories of Vietnam. Therefore, I believe that the author is depicting how Saeng is maturing and coping with the changes in her life by concluding the story with this statement.
I surmise that what the author intends to convey is that during winter, the hibiscus endeavors to withstand the cold. While most plants simply perish, the hibiscus confronts it directly.

I posit that the author includes this passage to preclude leaving the audience in speculation regarding what would transpire next. The quote “I will take the test again” implies that although Saeng may have failed the test related to the plant, she will never abandon her efforts and that when spring arrives, she will make another attempt. I sense that the author incorporated this to offer a more profound comprehension of the experience of leaving one's homeland to relocate to an unfamiliar and incomprehensible place, akin to the flower - related circumstances in the story. When she reflected on the plants and their fragrance, it rekindled the nostalgic sentiments she harbored about her homeland and the close bond she shared with her grandmother. She was accustomed to plants growing freely rather than being confined in pots with limited space for growth. Witnessing this sight caused Saeng to break down and weep. In conclusion, I believe that the author appended the paragraph at the end to facilitate understanding and to convey that although Saeng may be in a new environment with a distinct culture, she will persevere in taking the test until she deems herself to have passed it.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” deliberately included that final paragraph. In fact, the story is enhanced by its presence. In the last paragraph, the statement “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” holds significance. When the author enumerates those natural phenomena that will occur, it symbolizes rebirth, a fresh start, and a new opportunity, which is precisely what Saeng requires for her driver's license test. The author effectively employed these symbols to instill hope for the girl to endure her difficult period. Ultimately, the story attains a sense of completeness and closure with that last paragraph, rendering it a well - rounded narrative.

I opine that the reason the author concludes the story with that paragraph is that it is an edifying tale from which one can glean knowledge. The author did so to enable readers to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the story. It states that “Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam.” By reading this, it informs us about the events that transpired immediately prior to the commencement of the story, thereby facilitating a better comprehension. To me, it serves to encapsulate the entire narrative. Hence, I believe that is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph.

I am of the opinion that the author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story in the manner she does due to Saeng's agreement to retake the test. She desires to take the test when the snow thaws, the geese return, and the hibiscus begins to bud. In essence, when spring arrives, she will be prepared for the test. Saeng asserts in the story, “It’s the flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to endure the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” I surmise that Saeng is utilizing this as a guiding beacon since she has recently relocated from Vietnam. She intends to persevere and employ the plant as a symbol. She will make another attempt for her driver's license at the onset of spring.

The author employed the statement “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because it symbolizes that her mother is rejuvenating, awakening, and restoring herself. And Saeng declared that she would retake the driving test when that occurs. She was profoundly sorrowful about failing. “I – I failed the test.” She appeared to be both embarrassed and sad. Thus, that final paragraph effectively depicts what Saeng intends to do. She is going to adopt an optimistic outlook and restore herself to return and pass the test.

As the narrator, I appreciate this paragraph in the story because the hibiscus is a valuable plant, and having a garden is a personal choice, much like her mother's decision to cultivate hot peppers. A garden serves as a means to embrace diversity, such as the various types of foods one can plant and the different plants in the world, for example, roses, lilies, and other such flora.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as she is attempting to surmount an obstacle. Failing the driver's test was a setback for Saeng, so she plans to retake it. She intends to use the hibiscus as motivation since the winter for the hibiscus is akin to overcoming an obstacle.

I believe the reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is that it demonstrates the profound significance it holds for her and indicates that she truly cares. By showing her concern, she will retake the test.

She concludes the narrative with that paragraph as she intends to inform everyone that she experiences the utmost comfort during spring. It further indicates that she is eager for the geese and the hibiscus to commence budding since it is her favored time of the year.

Saeng is ill - at - ease in her surroundings and has not acclimated to the changes from her place of origin. She spots the hibiscus and decides to purchase it as it evokes memories of her home in @LOCATION2. When she brings it home, her mother initially appears astounded by the price Saeng paid, but then becomes more empathetic upon realizing that she misses @LOCATION2. Saeng states that she will retake her test in the spring, also implying that she will alter her attitude towards residing in @LOCATION1.
I surmise that the author reaches that conclusion in the story as he alludes to the return of the geese.

The author arrives at such a conclusion as she aims to demonstrate that Saeng was not surrendering. I assert this because she relocated to a place she disliked and knew no one. The author endeavors to convey that regardless of the circumstances, one should not give up and maintain faith. By the end, Saeng has confidence in herself that she can pass the test next time. By @MONTH1, she has likely understood that being in an undesired place does not mean one cannot persevere.

The author concludes the story in that manner to convey to the reader the notion that one should not quit upon failure. When Saeng declared that she would return and take the test again when spring arrives, it exemplifies her resolve not to quit and the idea that life will continue. This is the reason I believe the author chose to conclude the story in this way.

I surmise that the author concludes the narrative with this paragraph to convey that she is disinclined to abandon the battle against her homesickness. When she first acquired that plant, it evoked recollections of her former residence, manifesting the depth of her longing for that place. By declaring that she will undertake the test anew, it demonstrates her refusal to let this setback vanquish her in her new abode and novel existence.

The author concludes the narrative by having Saeng vow to illustrate that Saeng possesses the capacity and indeed has the ability to surmount obstacles. Saeng perceives herself as a failure. Her hibiscus symbolizes the courage required to overcome the obstacle, which is the driving test she failed. The geese represent survival and the tenacity to never yield, to exert one's utmost effort to achieve success.

The author concludes the story in this manner because the girl within the narrative bears a resemblance to the flower itself. Just as the flower will bloom, Saeng will retake the test; both are afforded a fresh beginning. Concluding the story in this fashion leaves the reader with a positive sentiment. It is a concise ending yet one imbued with profound meaning. “...and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” I believe the final sentence is nearly inspirational, inspiring one to commence afresh, just as Saeng does.

The author concludes the story with “When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” for numerous valid reasons. Among these reasons is that she will persevere and adapt to her new life in Canada. She intends to transform her lifestyle and endeavor to assimilate into her new culture. She will also have to revisit the memory of her grandmother and desires to handle it more adeptly. “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eye now swept over her.” She aspires to cope with the loss more effectively. The author aims to emphasize that the story is not yet at its conclusion.

There exist numerous reasons why the narrator might have chosen to conclude with this paragraph. Firstly, as it marks the onset of winter, the hibiscus will not reappear until spring. Moreover, since it is the denouement of the story, it serves as an apt way to end, as it parallels the conclusion of the hibiscus's cycle and the story itself. The final paragraph also succinctly summarizes the narrative, being brief yet charming. This renders it an excellent ending for the story. It diverges from most story endings, thus making it distinctive, as most stories do not revolve around nature. In conclusion, there are multiple justifications for the narrator's choice to end the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph to illustrate how individuals can reclaim their resolve. At the onset of the story, Saeng is disheartened subsequent to failing her driving examination. Upon sighting the Hibiscus, she is inundated with recollections of the past and weeps. Her mother's benevolence prompts Saeng to draw fortitude from the flower, which, as her mother asserts, is "robust enough to endure the frigid months here." Anticipating that the Hibiscus will blossom in the spring, Saeng renews her determination to pass the test.

The author concludes with this response as he endeavors to convey that Saeng will replicate her actions but this time be more beneficial in the garden for her mother. She will exert greater effort in her schoolwork and focus less on gardening.

Saeng's personality in this narrative exhibits determination and self - assurance. I surmise that she believes she can engage in more sophisticated endeavors with diverse plants. I also opine that this is an ideal hobby experience for an individual who has an affinity for plants. I perceive that by @MONTH1, Saeng has achieved her goals of planting. I think that by @MONTH1, she desires to pursue her career in gardening. When she declared that when the plants revive, she would retake the test, I believe she implies that she is willing to explore more plant species. I think that by @MONTH1, she has acquired this planting experience from her mother. To me, this has been a family tradition. Saeng will likely have children and instruct them about various types of flowers.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph to demonstrate that Saeng is anticipating her life with an optimistic perspective. It indicates that she will no longer be despondent due to the changes in her life. The hibiscus serves as a literary device for the story's plot. When alterations occur to the hibiscus, corresponding changes transpire in the story. Initially, Saeng is without the hibiscus and feels despairing. When she beholds it, she reminisces about her past and is sorrowful. Once she plants it, circumstances start to improve. She begins to embrace the change when the last paragraph states, "when they return... and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," which shows that Saeng is viewing her future positively, and with this positive transformation, the hibiscus is now commencing to bloom. The author concludes the story symbolically, which aids in expressing the story's themes.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph "Saeng vowed silently to herself" because Saeng wishes to act in due time and season. During the "winter season," the land or soil was so frigid that plants were unable to grow appropriately. "Hibiscus costs nineteen dollars," and Saeng failed the test. "There was a frail, wiry beauty to Saeng's mother that touched Saeng deeply"; her mother radiates when she tends to the plants. All these are descriptions that hark back to the past, where Saeng wants to make amends, shine like her mother, and also pass the test.

At the conclusion of the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng states, “When they return, in the spring, when the snow dissipates and the geese migrate back and the hibiscus begins to bud, then I shall retake that test.” When she utters this, she is alluding to her driver's test. She declares she will retake the test as she is reminded that her family did not surrender; they relocated to @LOCATION1 for a new beginning. “A plant she had forgotten lured her back to her childhood realm.” After failing, she spots these flowers, which reminds her that she has never quit before. Thus, she will not do so now either.

The author endeavors to convey a sense of optimism for Saeng in her new nation. After noting her failure in the test, presumably a citizenship examination, the author aims to conclude the narrative with something that reassures the reader. Evidently, this test held significance as Saeng could not even meet her mother's gaze. This was likely the reason she purchased the flower for her mother. The ending reassures the reader so that one does not wonder how things will transpire for Saeng.

The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph to inform us that she will attempt to locate that flower to evoke memories of her former homeland. To demonstrate that they will return and it will endure, even though it is not from the place she desired. In the story, it states, “I failed the test,” indicating that Saeng had bought the hibiscus, which was not genuine or what she had envisioned. In the final paragraph, she asserts she will retake that test. Stating she will seek the winter hibiscus as it used to be in her homeland. She hopes they will survive and that she will discover a flower similar to it, as in the last paragraph it reads, “Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will retake that test,” signifying she hopes and prays she will find one akin to that of her old homeland.
The author sought to conclude the story expeditiously, which is why he ended it with this particular passage.

When spring arrives and all the snow thaws, she intends to sow new seeds. The author concludes thus because she did not perform well on the test initially. However, in the subsequent year, she will tend to her plants and then retake the test to secure a passing grade. The narrative "Winter Hibiscus" revolves around a young girl named Saeng, along with her mother and grandmother. Flowers hold great aesthetic appeal for them, and they dedicate the entire day to cultivating, selecting, and @CAPS1 them. Saeng lacked the courage to meet her mother's gaze.

The author concludes the story with the given saying as it demonstrates that she has self - confidence. Despite failing the test, she realizes she can retake it and is certain of passing. Initially, she was disheartened by the result. However, when her mother spoke with her, it instilled a sense of confidence, enabling her to face the retest with the belief that she could succeed. This paragraph implies that upon the conclusion of winter, when the geese return from the southern regions and her favored plant, which was native to her former homeland, reappears, she will recommence an endeavor she previously attempted. This time, she will approach it with heightened confidence. This is my interpretation of its meaning.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it effectively summarizes the entire narrative and resolves the conflict of Saeng failing her driver's test. When Saeng declared, "… I will take that test again," it exemplified her determination to pass the examination and her willingness to make another attempt. Since the conflict has been resolved, introducing a new conflict would be necessary to sustain the story's momentum. Thus, the author opts to conclude it. This excerpt from the last paragraph also draws a parallel between Saeng's struggles and those of the geese. Just as geese encounter hardships, Saeng faced difficulties in obtaining her driver's license. Similar to the geese, she will confront challenges again.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the narrative in a well - crafted and harmonious manner. The author chose to end with that specific paragraph to illustrate that Saeng would not be dissuaded, despite being far from home. At the onset of the story, she was in a downward spiral; she had failed a test, and the hibiscus made her feel nostalgic. When she arrived home, her mother greeted her with kind words, acting as a source of solace, preparing food without peppers and bitter melons. This gesture allowed Saeng to perceive the positive aspects of life, preventing her from giving up and instilling confidence that she would pass the test.

In the narrative, Saeng fails her driving examination. As she traverses back home, she spots a familiar plant. Subsequently, she proceeds to a florist and discovers that the plant is a hibiscus. She then purchases the plant with her meager funds as it evokes memories of her homeland and childhood. It also reminds her of her grandmother, whom she left behind, thus forging a connection with the plant. Moreover, she observes geese flying overhead, migrating south for the winter. She remarks, “When they return,” signifying when the geese fly north for @DATE1. And “when the snow thaws,” indicating when it becomes warmer and spring commences. “When this hibiscus begins to bud,” meaning when spring arrives and the plant starts to blossom, she will “retake that test.” In other words, she states that she will retake the driving test she failed when spring comes. She allocates the winter for practice and preparation for the test. She vows to herself that by spring, she will be ready to take the test and this time, she will succeed.

She expressed this to demonstrate the tenacity required to achieve success, regardless of the number of failures. One must rise and persevere. She also showcases her bravery in this manner, as it demands considerable fortitude for someone to confront failure and then attempt again. She refuses to accept defeat and endeavors to redeem her setback, hence declaring her intention to try once more. This is the rationale behind her concluding the story in such a way.

The author concludes the story with this particular paragraph. It is speculated that the author does so to inform readers of what the protagonist will undertake in the upcoming spring. This may also inspire them to envision an additional narrative, as they will know that she will take the test in the spring.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the tale with that paragraph because when winter arrives, the plant she adores will vanish. The flower had brought her good fortune, leading her to say, “When the snow melts in spring, the geese return, and this hibiscus starts to bud, then I will retake that test.” The flower held great significance for her. She mentioned, “That rich, sweet fragrance was also familiar.” She was comparing the flower's scent to that of her grandmother's shell; they were identical.
The author concludes the story in this fashion because she intends to return and repeat the same actions in the subsequent year.

The author concludes the narrative with this because she desires to retake the examination. This is due to her aspiration to pass the test for her mother. Consequently, she brought home the flower to offer an apology to her mother.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as everything within the narrative will recur, such as the seasonal transitions, and one cannot plant or cultivate during winter. For instance, she discussed how the plants bear no resemblance to her homeland, yet she must adapt to the reality that she is not at home and acclimate to her surroundings. I posit this because if she fails to do so, she will merely be a discontented individual fretting about her place of origin.

The author concludes the response by stating that when spring arrives and the hibiscus begins to bud, she will retake the test. This is because I believe she experiences hope and faith. I assert this as the girl has recently relocated from her home and feels profoundly lonely and depressed as she yearns to return home. She is nostalgic for her past, and when she beholds the plant, it imparts a sense of comfort as if she were at home. When she utters, “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” I think she says this because she is distressed about failing the test, and the plant offers her comfort, which instills in her the faith and hope that she will pass the test in spring.
When they return, Saeng silently vowed to herself that in spring, when the snow melts, the geese come back, and the hibiscus starts to bud, she will take that test once more.

In “@CAPS1 Hibiscus” by @PERSON1, the author selects the last paragraph as it aligns with the tone, the hope, and the symbolism of the essay. The tone of the story leans towards a despondent mood since she failed the driver's test, leaving her extremely distraught. Her recollections of her former country start to affect her when she sees the winter hibiscus. “And in the warm, moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” She misses Vietnam deeply, and seeing this plant in the store evokes flash - backs. The onset of winter makes her feel as though all hope is lost. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had regarded as strange before had, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, become almost familiar to her now.” To her, the unfamiliar things are starting to seem the same year after year, with no new hope, no new experiences, just the same old routine day by day. This plant truly tears her apart, solely due to its symbolism. “She found that she was still too shaky to utter the word 'home,' lest she burst into tears again.” She cannot say “home” because home, for her, is not in the United States but in Vietnam. This winter hibiscus triggers an outburst of intense emotions related to her past. Thus, the last paragraph more aptly conveys how, when her hope is restored in spring, she will simply try again. The tone, hope, and symbolism all support the last paragraph, which is why it fits where it does.

This was an exceptionally captivating story that delineated all the adversities this young girl had endured. The author concluded it in a highly engaging manner. Upon the story's end, I mused on how delightfully it concluded. I believe the author executed a commendable task. She managed to depict all the tribulations that Saeng had undergone, as if they were the severe winter. Then, as the author stated, “as the snow melts away;…”, I surmise this demonstrates that even though Saeng's problems appear interminable and harsh, one day they will dissipate, and things will regain their beauty, akin to the budding flower in the springtime. The author concludes the narrative with the paragraph stating - “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” because she perceives that when the hibiscus blossoms, she too can flourish by passing the test. She too can persevere through the frigid months. “like the geese she lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.” Just as the geese, Saeng is realizing to be proud of herself and that there will be other opportunities. One should not constantly doubt oneself as there will be other chances. One should not be afraid to attempt again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it implies that she will return after winter to tend to it. The author concludes the story with the paragraph regarding the geese as it illustrates how Saeng, similar to the geese, will adapt to her new environment. The reason the author penned the conclusion paragraph was to illustrate that Saeng is anticipating a more promising future. The author concludes this paragraph within the story as it possesses an appealing cadence and serves to convey to the intended audience that regardless of the adversities encountered in life, one should steadfastly pursue what one deems most advantageous. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it demonstrates that Saeng is commencing to assume responsibility for her academic pursuits. For instance, within the story, it was evident that she prioritized the garden over her schoolwork.

Saeng was discussing the evaluation of the plants, ascertaining whether the geese favored the locations where she had planted them. I am cognizant of this because she mentioned the geese in the preceding paragraph, and the geese signified approval when she planted the hibiscus.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph since the narrative predominantly revolved around the hibiscus. Saeng stated that when spring arrives and the hibiscus begins to bud, she will retake the test. The hibiscus serves as a poignant reminder of her homeland in bygone days.

I believe the author concludes the narrative with that paragraph as it pertains to a new commencement. Moreover, regarding what lies ahead at this new juncture, she expresses her intention to retake the test.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as she attains a more sanguine state of mind upon discovering a flower that evokes her homeland. Minfong Ho concludes the story with a phrase - dialogue as it pertains to the central theme of the narrative. By stating, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" (Ho), the author showcases Saeng's affection and aspiration for self - growth for her parents, demonstrating her maturity.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey to the reader that Saeng intends to retake the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the plant has yet to bud, the geese are departing, and she failed the test, all of which have plunged her into a state of melancholy. The author concludes the narrative in this manner due to numerous reasons. I surmise that the author concluded the story with this paragraph as they intended to showcase her dedication to her essence, particularly regarding the hibiscus. I opine that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng perceives that the opportune moment to retake her driving test coincides with the budding of the hibiscus. Additionally, another reason could be that the author wishes to highlight her tenacity.

I conjecture that the author concludes the final paragraph of the story because it serves as a moral compass for the narrative. Saeng is an exceedingly helpful young woman to her mother. The author crafted the ending sentence to render the story more captivating for the reader and to retain their engagement until the conclusion.
The author concludes the story with that sentence because she intended to convey to the reader that she will undertake this again when the hibiscus returns to season.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because when interacting with flowers and nature, there are seasons when the flowers do not bloom, such as winter. Saeng pledges to herself, "In the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and this hibiscus is in bloom, then I will retake that test." The hibiscus serves as a metaphor for Saeng's childhood. Having grown up in Vietnam and relocated to the @LOCATION2, she yearns for her homeland, and the flowers trigger a flood of nostalgic memories, causing her to break down in tears. Adapting to change, particularly moving to a foreign country, is arduous. However, planting the winter hibiscus is her coping mechanism. She realizes that she will gradually adjust, as "many of the things she had once regarded as strange had become... almost familiar." She vows to retake the driver's test when the hibiscus blossoms because, like a flower, she too undergoes transformation. When the hibiscus overcomes the frigid, dismal winter and flourishes, Saeng will know she is prepared to retake the test, as the flower symbolizes her journey through change. The geese in the story also represent change; they migrate south in winter to evade the cold and return home when it warms up. Similarly, Saeng will defer the test in winter but face it in spring when she feels at ease. This shows how nature's cycles mirror Saeng's personal growth and her ability to face challenges.

In the narrative “Winter Hibiscus” penned by Minfong Ho, the author chose to conclude it with the statement “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. When the snows dissipate and the geese return and this hibiscus is in bud, then I will attempt that test once more.” This demonstrates that despite the protagonist Saeng having faced failure previously, she will persevere and try again. Saeng asserts that if both can overcome challenges through perseverance, so can she, and this time, she will achieve success. The flower is driven to re - bud, the geese are impelled to return in spring, and the main character is motivated to pass the test. Minfong Ho, the author of “Winter Hibiscus,” included that quote as the final line of the story to inspire. To encourage individuals to persevere on the journey of life and, in the event of task failure, to make another attempt. Thus, the author offers inspiration to aid in the continuation of one's life.

In the narrative "Winter Hibiscus" penned by Minfong Ho, a adolescent named Saeng relocates from Vietnam to the United States. The concluding paragraph reads, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows dissipate and the geese return and this hibiscus is in bud, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the tale with this paragraph for multiple reasons. Namely, Saeng was deeply distressed about failing her test and was reminded of her homeland as well as the adaptations she had to make during this relocation. The hibiscus plant instills in Saeng the hope to persevere in her journey even when circumstances become arduous. Winter represents a period of tribulation and sorrow for this plant, just as failing the test and being away from her true home are Saeng's times of distress. The conclusion of winter offers both the plant and Saeng an opportunity for a fresh start and a renewed sense of hope. Saeng will find it feasible to surmount hardships if she continues to draw comfort from her past.

Upon relocating to America, she beheld all the resplendent flowers in bloom during spring. A particular blossom, a hibiscus, captivated her attention. Intrigued, she visited a florist to inquire if they had it. Back in her native land, these blossoms grew untamed, sprouting from the crevices in the walls. The blossom evoked memories of her grandmother with her long, freshly - washed gray hair.

In the passage “Winter Hibiscus” by Monfong Ho, the quote “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again” symbolizes a novel journey in the new country where she resides. During the test, Saeng grapples with a personal conflict, yearning for her homeland as she states, “I – failed the test.” This test holds greater significance than mere failure; it assesses her ability to adapt and function in her new country, and she fell short. The aforementioned “When they came back…” quote can be profoundly analyzed, with the snow representing her obstacles and the hibiscus symbolizing herself. Once the obstacles dissipate and she blossoms into a stronger individual, she will be ready to retake the test.
She shall return to the place where her journey commenced. It is a cyclical path, and she will find herself back at the starting point the following year.

I am of the opinion that the author brings the story to a close with this paragraph: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This is because the budding of that flower would instill in her a sense of confidence regarding everything. The rationale behind my thinking is that the flower evokes memories of her homeland from the past. It is essentially as if she possesses a small piece of home within her new abode. An instance that exemplifies this is, “Not like the kind we had before.” This is elucidating that the new hibiscus is similar yet not identical to the one from her homeland, thus reminding her of home. This is the reason I am convinced that the author concludes the story in this manner.

The author brings the story to a close with this paragraph to demonstrate that Saeng is not merely going to capitulate. She is going to surmount the problem. This constitutes an excellent approach to ending the story because the entire narrative revolves around overcoming difficulties, and if Saeng were to simply give up, it would mar the story. Just as she was capable of relocating from her native land, she will ultimately pass the test. The mother, too, was able to overcome certain obstacles, such as moving away from her homeland and having to plant entirely new flora. Evidently, she misses the former plants, which can be discerned from the way she recognized her gift. Nevertheless, she is able to cope with this, just as Saeng will handle her test the next time.

All aspects within the story are on the verge of transformation. The winter will transition into spring, the snow will melt and dissipate, the geese will return, the hibiscus will commence budding, and Saeng will also undergo change and maturation. Saeng bears a resemblance to the hibiscus plant; just as the plant is out of place along the road, Saeng is out of place in the new country, and she must adapt in the same way as the hibiscus plant. The plant appears different in the United States compared to Vietnam as it has matured and grown. This is precisely what Saeng must do; she must mature and develop in this new country. For example, Saeng noted how distinct the plant looked in the shop window compared to how it appeared in her home country. She was, in fact, observing herself and how different she seemed as well. The purpose of placing the paragraph at the very end was to illustrate that she had already matured, and positioning it at the end serves to show that she has grown. Placing it at the beginning would not yield the same impact. The hibiscus plant was able to endure the harsh winter's transformation. Saeng is also capable of doing so, and she made a silent vow to take that test again once she has matured, just as the surrounding elements have.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” employs this paragraph to bring her story to a close as it serves as a symbol of Saeng's future. “Winter Hibiscus” symbolizes Saeng for multiple reasons. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the tale with the paragraph, “When they return, Saeng silently vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts, the geese come back, and this hibiscus is in bud, then I will retake that test.” The author most probably selected this as the final paragraph to assist the reader in comprehending the message. The author concluded the story with this paragraph for a single reason. That reason is that Saeng believes she failed because she acquired a fake plant rather than a genuine one. For example, she stated, “It's not like the one at home.” This is why the author concludes with this paragraph.

When they return, Saeng promised herself, in the spring when the snows recede and the geese migrate back and this hibiscus begins to blossom, then I will retake that test." In the text, when the mother stated, "It's flowers aren't as resplendent, yet it's robust enough to endure the frigid months here, this winter hibiscus. That's what matters."
