In the short story, "Winter Hibiscus," penned by Minfong Ho, the author incorporates a paragraph at the conclusion, proclaiming that the protagonist, Saeng, will retake her driving test. Ho includes this paragraph to demonstrate Saeng's resolve to adapt. Saeng is newly arrived in the United States; she and her mother relocated here from Vietnam. Throughout the narrative, she reminisces about her life in Vietnam, her grandmother, and the flowers there. "Where was my...hibiscus hedge?... Her gentle grandmother?" While at the flower shop, Saeng discovers a hibiscus, a flower also found in Vietnam. She observes how it has adapted to survive the winter here. As she plants the flower in her backyard, she makes a solemn vow to herself to pass the driving test the following spring. She, too, desires to acclimate to the new environment and be able to reside here without excessively longing for home. This vow she made is included in the last paragraph. The author included it to illustrate that Saeng, too, wishes to adapt to her surroundings and pass the driving test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to elucidate the true essence of the hibiscus. The hibiscus holds symbolic significance for Saeng in multiple ways, but most crucially, it represents transformation, growth, and the capacity to surmount obstacles. Upon beholding it, she is inundated with childhood recollections and nostalgia. Nevertheless, if she wishes to evolve as an individual, she must adjust to her new abode. She will persevere here, just as the hibiscus will endure through the winter. Additionally, Saeng vows that "in the spring" when "this hibiscus is in bud, then I will take that test again." She is resolute in achieving success, and the hibiscus itself epitomizes victory over obstacles. It symbolizes survival and perseverance through life's disappointments and challenges, from failing a driver's test to commencing a new life in an unfamiliar and foreign land. The author's decision to end the story with this paragraph showcases Saeng's ultimate comprehension of her strength through the symbol of the hibiscus.

I surmise that the author concludes the paragraph in such a manner because he/she aimed to convey a crucial message to the audience. The message the author sought to impart was that despite failing the test, she would endeavor again the following year. An instance of this is the exact quote, "In the spring when the snow thaws and the geese return and the hibiscus is in bloom, then I will take the test again." This is the rationale behind my belief that the author concludes the story in this way.

The author incorporates the story within this paragraph as, given that Saeng failed her driver's test for the first time when the hibiscus begins to bud, it symbolizes a transformation in her life. Moreover, Saeng used to have hibiscus flowers at her former residence in Vietnam; thus, when the flower buds, it can signify that she has a new home.

The author concludes the narrative with the statement, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The rationale behind this conclusion is that it is crucial for Saeng to feel a sense of belonging. When the hibiscus buds, it will evoke memories of her home, offering her solace. When she experiences tranquility and a feeling of home, she will perform better on the test.

The author concludes the story with that particular paragraph to demonstrate that she is neither relinquishing her new home nor forgetting her old one. Her determination not to give up is evident when she brings the flower home to plant, which also indicates that she will not forget her former abode. Additionally, when she states, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” it shows that she is giving her new home another opportunity and not surrendering. Another instance is when it is mentioned, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had regarded as peculiar before had, through the quiet recurrence of season after season, become nearly familiar to her now.” Here, she is embracing the changes and giving her new home a fresh chance, refusing to abandon it.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because she is prepared to repeat the same activities the following year. She relishes spending time with her mother, has an affinity for plants, and enjoys having a good time with her mother. These are some of the reasons why she concludes the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph since the hibiscus offers solace. After Saeng failed her driving test and was new to the place, she was exasperated and yearning for her actual home in Vietnam. The hibiscus reminded her of her grandmother. She writes, “She closed her eyes and inhaled deeply as the fragrance permeated her lungs.” After Saeng smelled the flower, it reminded her of “combing her grandmother’s long grey hair, freshly washed,” bringing her comfort during a period of disappointment. Even though she did not have her grandmother present, the flower provided her with consolation. Despite her disappointment, the hibiscus was “exquisite,” and as she uttered the [CAPS1] word “dokor malik,” meaning hibiscus, she “relished the sensation of the word on her tongue.” The joy and comfort that the flower brings to Saeng are what make her decide to take the test again in the spring when “the snow melts and the hibiscus is budding,” thereby infusing joy, love, and comfort into the reader as they empathize with Saeng's emotions.

The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph as it correlates the concept of the hibiscus with Saeng and her circumstances in a foreign country. It demonstrates that Saeng is leveraging the hibiscus and its capacity to adapt as a source of inspiration. Throughout the story, Saeng recounts how she had consistently encountered the hibiscus in her native land. Her mother explains to her that the hibiscus she purchased differs slightly from the one back home. However, she attributes this to its resilience and its ability to acclimate to the frigid winter environment of the United States. This is precisely what Saeng utilizes as inspiration. Although she may have failed her license test, she emulates the hibiscus's actions to set a personal goal. The plant endures a cold and snowy winter but flourishes and blossoms in the spring. Saeng intends to utilize this time to study and prepare, and she will approach the test with confidence. The paragraph with which the author concludes illustrates the connection Saeng established between her situation and that of the plant.

The adage “If at first you don't succeed, try, try again” is frequently employed by parents to encourage their children or by coaches to motivate their teams. This quote is also applicable to Saeng's predicament in the short story “Winter Hibiscus.” Saeng fails her driver's test and, while walking home afterward, notices a hibiscus flower that evokes memories of her homeland. Sorrow engulfs her, and she purchases the plant to soothe her grief. She brings it home and is initially rebuked by her mother but later thanked for the purchase. As Saeng is planting the hibiscus, she hears the honking of Canada geese, which had by then become familiar to her. The text states, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had once regarded as strange had, through the quiet recurrence of season after season, become familiar to her.” This quote exemplifies the adaptation she had to undergo upon arriving in @LOCATION1. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that, like the hibiscus flower, she will adapt to the challenges and hardships of @LOCATION1. The hibiscus inspires her to persevere and attempt the license test again, just as the plant persevered through the winter.

The author concludes the story in this manner because Saeng experiences a sense of solace with the hibiscus flower. The flower evokes memories of her homeland and her grandmother. As the story states, “The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's long gray hair.” It is evident that she misses her homeland but always keeps it close to her heart, regardless of her location. The text describes it as “yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and delicate flowers with purplish petals and white centers.” She appears to have a profound connection with nature and all its appealing attributes. After failing the test, she purchased her “@CAPS1 Malik” flower as a source of comfort. She and her mother decided to plant it in their garden, and during this process, Saeng received a significant boost of confidence to retake the test. This connection between Saeng and the hibiscus flower underscores the emotional support and inspiration it provides her, ultimately influencing her decision to face her challenges anew.

She draws a parallel between the paragraph and the story to relate it to the school environment. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to accentuate Saeng's resolve to surmount the hurdles of her past experiences. For instance, the story commences with Saeng taking a “test.” As she revisits her memories in the greenhouse, she begins to succumb to her emotions. “A wave of loss so profound and intense that it stung Saeng's eyes now washed over her.” Subsequently, she purchases the plant and takes it home to her mother, informing her that she “failed.” Her mother then exhibits understanding and supports Saeng's vow to retake the “test.” The narrator emphasizes Saeng's determination to overcome the difficulties of her past and forge ahead into the future, highlighting her resilience and the transformative power of her experiences.

Owing to her academic pursuits, she was engaged in the study of flowers within a verdant garden. Evidently, she failed the examination. It is my contention that the author concluded the narrative with that specific paragraph to convey that Saeng was not relinquishing her efforts. Originally hailing from Vietnam, Saeng relocated to the United States. She yearned deeply for her homeland as everything seemed different. “It’s not a real one,” Saeng murmured. “I mean, not like the kind we had back home.” She found herself too tremulous to utter the words “at home.” Once Saeng finally recognized that she was beginning to acclimate to life in the United States, she resolved to attempt the driver's test once more. “When they return in the spring, when the snows thaw and the geese come back and this hibiscus starts to bud, then I will take that test again.” In essence, the author's choice of conclusion effectively portrays Saeng's resilience and hope.

I surmise that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the protagonist appears to attain a sense of comfort upon sighting the geese and cultivating the hibiscus during winter, ensuring its survival. I opine that the reason the author concludes the story with this paragraph is to enable the reader to envision the subsequent events once spring arrives for Saeng. The author concluded the story with that particular paragraph because, like the geese, the character will return to make another attempt. Moreover, it demonstrates to the readers that the character's spirit cannot be vanquished by a single winter and that she will persevere until she accomplishes her goals. The author of the narrative “Winter Hibiscus” most plausibly concludes it with the paragraph where Saeng pledges to retake the test to illustrate that even amidst arduous circumstances and novel situations, an individual must never succumb to despair and surrender. In the story “The Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, it delineates the challenges Saeng encountered upon migrating to a foreign country. I am convinced that the author concludes the narrative "Winter Hibiscus," penned by Minfong Ho, with the line "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" because she endeavors to illustrate how past recollections can be transmuted into hope and resolve. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” incorporated the final paragraph to convey to readers that she would be progressing forward while still cherishing memories of her native country. Prior to discovering the flower, the author deeply yearned for her homeland. “It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng murmured. “I mean not like the kind we had at—at…” She found herself too tremulous to utter the words “at home,” and eventually broke into sobs again. She longed for her home in the other country and struggled to overcome this sentiment. The author was yet unable to accept her new country as her home. For Saeng, the hibiscus flower rekindled memories of her old country, rendering it even more arduous to move on. “One of the blossoms had fallen off, and Saeng delicately picked it up and inhaled its fragrance. Saeng could almost sense the fine strands of her grandmother’s freshly washed long gray hair as she combed it with the fine - toothed buffalo - horn comb.” The flower was an overwhelming reminder of the past. She finally possessed something from home that she could hold. “Gently, she closed her palm around it and clasped it tightly. That, at least, she could cling to.” The author now had a tangible object to remind her of home. This was the initial step towards finally moving on. Now Saeng required some time to acclimate to her new country. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many things she had previously regarded as peculiar had now become nearly familiar to her.” Saeng needed just a bit more time, akin to a period of hibernation. She determined that once the hibiscus emerged from hibernation and was ready to bloom, she would be prepared to accept her new country and move forward. Saeng decided that the interval between fall and spring would be sufficient to adjust to her new life. By taking this step, Saeng would be moving on. The author included this final paragraph so that readers could infer that Saeng would take the last steps towards accepting her new country and moving on by taking this step, although she would reflect on her old country through the winter hibiscus.

Moreover, when readers learn that the girl failed the test, they will be eager to know if she retakes it and the reasons behind her decision if she does.

The author concludes the narrative with the statement “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself...,” as it provides the reader with a conclusive ending. The author concludes the story with “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is done to illustrate that Saeng is adapting to her new country and making decisions, much like she did in her homeland. The author concludes the narrative with this paragraph to demonstrate the ultimate determination and fortitude bestowed upon Saeng. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by @CAPS1 Ho, the author concludes the tale with a potent ending. In the narrative "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the story with the paragraph to illustrate the frequency with which Saeng is assailed by her memories. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" penned by @CAPS1 Ho, a young girl named Saeng failed her driver's test on that particular day. Subsequently, she vowed that she would retake the test come spring. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author Minfong Ho concludes with the statement, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The flower symbolizes something to her that instills motivation and resolve. Everyone has something that spurs them on in life, and for Saeng, it is her plant. The author also provides a hint as to the story's progression when the flower buds.

Saeng is not merely disappointed from failing her driver's test; she is also distraught and longing for her homeland of Vietnam. As she walks home, she discovers a small fragment of Vietnam right in the United States. She purchases the exquisite winter hibiscus, or saebba, to evoke memories of her past. The conclusion of this story intertwines the two distinct countries, cultures, and almost parallel worlds that constitute her life. When she says, "when they come back," she is referring to the geese. To her, the geese symbolize her life in @LOCATION2 and how she has become accustomed to it. The hibiscus is also a symbol of her life, representing her past in Vietnam. It rekindles memories, and buying that plant was like acquiring a small piece of home. When the "hibiscus is budding," she will attempt the test once more. When this small piece of home flourishes, she will try again. When she is more firmly established in the @CAPS1 culture while still maintaining a strong connection to her own, she will be ready.

I surmise that the author concluded the story with this paragraph because it demonstrates that Saeng is not a quitter. Saeng eagerly anticipates the return of the Hibiscus. When the Hibiscus reappears, she will retake the test and prove to her mother that she is capable of success.

The reason the author concluded the story with this paragraph is that when Saeng saw the geese, she realized that when spring returns, she will be prepared to seek out different flowers. She also recalls the "Madagascar periwinkle" growing wild from the crevices in brick walls or tiled roofs. Essentially, the author indicates that she is ready to search for other plants that evoke memories of her homeland.
